questions.question: What is the basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision?
questions.explanation: The basic minimum illumination for satisfactory vision is accepted to be 15 - 20 foot candles. Theillumination requirements vary from as little as 5 foot candles in stairways and corridors to 100foot candles in some industries.

questions.question: A steel plant worker presented with sudden onset of bilateral hearing loss after hearing ablast in the plant. On examination, both his tympanic membranes were ruptured. Whatwould have been the minimum intensity of the blast to cause this injury?
questions.explanation: A minimum intensity of 160 dB can lead to rupture of the tympanic membrane, resulting inhearing loss.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of auditory fatigue that begins to appear with exposure tonoise at 90 dB.

questions.question: An airline ground staff officer with difficulty hearing is found to have permanent hearing losson follow up. Continuous exposure to sound above what intensity can cause this condition?

questions.question: Which of the following is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation?
questions.explanation: Rad is a unit of absorbed dose of radiation by tissue or material. It has been replaced by the SIunit which is gray (Gy).

questions.question: What is the SI unit of radiation dose equivalent?
questions.explanation: The SI unit of radiation dose equivalent is sievert (Sv).Dose equivalent (H) = Absorbed dose (D) x Quality factor (Q)The quality factor depends upon the density of ionization produced in the tissue by radiation. Thefactor Q for X-rays, y-rays and electrons is 1 and that for an alpha particle is 20.

questions.question: What is the permissible dose of manmade radiation per year?
questions.explanation: The permissible dose of manmade radiation is 5 rads per year.

questions.question: A young girl who is 1 month pregnant is concerned about a chest X-ray that she had taken 3weeks back. What is the dose of radiation below which deterministic effects on the fetus arenot seen?
questions.explanation: 606Deterministic effects on the fetus are not seen below 5 rads or 50 mSv of radiation.Dose limits of radiation exposure are:•Occupational exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 20 mSv/year averaged over 5consecutive years / 30 mSv in a year.••General public exposure - Effective dose should not exceed 1 mSv/year• Occupational exposure for pregnant staff - Effective dose to the fetus should not exceed1mSv/year (same as the general public).For pregnant patients who require diagnostics with exposure to ionising radiation, the radiationprotection principles are followed:• The exposure should be justified• The dose should be as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA principle)• The dose limit is not particularly specified as it involves a single time exposure to diagnosticradiation. Usually, the effective dose to the fetus is <1msv and deterministic effects to the fetusare not seen below 50 mSv (5 Rad).

questions.question: What was the 10 days rule in radiation related to?
questions.explanation: The 10 days rule in radiation was related to pregnancy. It is aimed at preventing unintentionalexposure of the embryo or fetus to radiation.This rule states that if a radiograph is being done on the abdomen or pelvis of a woman in herchildbearing age, then it should be done during the 10 days following the onset of menstruation.In most situations, there is growing evidence that strict adherence to the "ten-day rule" may beunnecessarily restrictive. Since organogenesis starts 3 to 5 weeks post-conception, it was felt thatradiation exposure in early pregnancy couldn't result in malformation. Based on this, it wassuggested to do away with the 10-day rule and replace it with a 28-day rule. This means thatradiological examination if justified, can be carried throughout the cycle until a period is missed.607
